body:
@eenticott-shell, would you kindly be able to have a quick look at this, whether this is already fixed by https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/1830?

@ngupta23, this may be fixed but is not yet in the stable version. Have you tried with 0.9.0 or the dev version?

issue.title: [BUG] Some time series not working for alphanumeric frequencies

labels.name: time_series
labels.description: Topics related to the time series

repository.name: pycaret
repository.description: An open-source, low-code machine learning library in Python

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**

Related to #1866 

10-minute frequency does not work for some models

Example notebook here: https://gist.github.com/ngupta23/cdea6111168d1671852bd95db4546d29

**To Reproduce**

```python
y = get_data("airline")

# Change index to 10 min interval
import pandas as pd
time_range = pd.date_range(pd.to_datetime('2019-01-01 00:00'), pd.to_datetime('2019-01-01 23:55'), freq='10Min')
y.index = time_range

exp = TimeSeriesExperiment()
exp.setup(data=y, fh=6, session_id=42)

# Works
model = exp.create_model("naive")

# Does not work
model = exp.create_model("exp_smooth")
```

```python
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
KeyError                                  Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-12-5294443a5a65> in <module>()
----> 1 model = exp.create_model("exp_smooth")

/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/pycaret/internal/pycaret_experiment/time_series_experiment.py in create_model(self, estimator, fold, round, cross_validation, fit_kwargs, verbose, **kwargs)
   1420             fit_kwargs=fit_kwargs,
   1421             verbose=verbose,
-> 1422             **kwargs,
   1423         )
   1424 

/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/pycaret/internal/pycaret_experiment/supervised_experiment.py in create_model(self, estimator, fold, round, cross_validation, predict, fit_kwargs, groups, refit, probability_threshold, verbose, system, add_to_model_list, X_train_data, y_train_data, metrics, display, **kwargs)
   1561             refit,
   1562             system,
-> 1563             display,
   1564         )
   1565 

/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/pycaret/internal/pycaret_experiment/time_series_experiment.py in _create_model_with_cv(self, model, data_X, data_y, fit_kwargs, round, cv, groups, metrics, refit, system, display)
   1549             return_train_score=False,
   1550             error_score=0,
-> 1551             **additional_scorer_kwargs,
   1552         )
   1553 

/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/pycaret/internal/pycaret_experiment/time_series_experiment.py in cross_validate_ts(forecaster, y, X, cv, scoring, fit_params, n_jobs, return_train_score, error_score, verbose, **additional_scorer_kwargs)
    173                 **additional_scorer_kwargs,
    174             )
--> 175             for train, test in get_folds(cv, y)
    176         )
    177     # raise key exceptions

/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/joblib/parallel.py in __call__(self, iterable)
   1052 
   1053             with self._backend.retrieval_context():
-> 1054                 self.retrieve()
   1055             # Make sure that we get a last message telling us we are done
   1056             elapsed_time = time.time() - self._start_time

/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/joblib/parallel.py in retrieve(self)
    931             try:
    932                 if getattr(self._backend, 'supports_timeout', False):
--> 933                     self._output.extend(job.get(timeout=self.timeout))
    934                 else:
    935                     self._output.extend(job.get())

/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/joblib/_parallel_backends.py in wrap_future_result(future, timeout)
    540         AsyncResults.get from multiprocessing."""
    541         try:
--> 542             return future.result(timeout=timeout)
    543         except CfTimeoutError as e:
    544             raise TimeoutError from e

/usr/lib/python3.7/concurrent/futures/_base.py in result(self, timeout)
    433                 raise CancelledError()
    434             elif self._state == FINISHED:
--> 435                 return self.__get_result()
    436             else:
    437                 raise TimeoutError()

/usr/lib/python3.7/concurrent/futures/_base.py in __get_result(self)
    382     def __get_result(self):
    383         if self._exception:
--> 384             raise self._exception
    385         else:
    386             return self._result

KeyError: "None of [PeriodIndex(['2019-01-01 20:00', '2019-01-01 20:10', '2019-01-01 20:20',\n             '2019-01-01 20:30', '2019-01-01 20:40', '2019-01-01 20:50'],\n            dtype='period[10T]', freq='10T')] are in the [index]"
```

**Expected behavior**
Models should work at 10 minute intervals

body:
>I am unable to install it directly from GitHub to check the latest dev version - https://gist.github.com/ngupta23/ddf3276510f0ecf5933291cbe63043d0

That won't work due to the C dependencies - you have to follow the install instructions locally with build requirements if you want to try it:
https://www.sktime.org/en/stable/installation.html

We're working on removing the C dependencies soon so install is easier... but they are still there, sorry.

@fkiraly I tested the `main` branch. It gives the same error

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33585645/150214629-d0ab0353-abd9-4e4f-b9b0-a0c20655bb14.png)

@ngupta23, I've confirmed the bug on python 3.9, windows, current dev.

I've also tried two other forecasters (naive and trend), and this error is *not* raised. This is, hence, possibly specific to the `statsmodels` adapter.

Instead, one gets this warning:
```
FutureWarning: casting period[10T] values to int64 with .astype(...) is deprecated and will raise in a future version.
```

This code seems to work as expected:
```python
from sktime.forecasting.base import ForecastingHorizon
fh=ForecastingHorizon([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6])
fh.to_absolute(cutoff = y.index[-1])
```
this gives
```
ForecastingHorizon(['2019-01-02 00:00', '2019-01-02 00:10', '2019-01-02 00:20',
             '2019-01-02 00:30', '2019-01-02 00:40', '2019-01-02 00:50'],
            dtype='period[10T]', is_relative=False)
```
(so I guess it's not the same bug as you fixed, @eenticott-shell)

@fkiraly It seems to be a more prevalent problem. I will try to list out specific issues.

## For statsmodels

The issue seems to be with `to_absolute_int` method of the ForecastingHorizon which is called from the adapter. At a 10 minute interval in PeriodIndex, it seems to be returning extremely large values for the integers.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33585645/150614706-a215f5cd-bdc6-4b7c-9994-bceeb68c700a.png)

## For PolynomialTrendForecaster

The issue seems to be with the calculation of X. It ends up with many more points because `_get_duration` does not seem to return the right number of points

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33585645/150616436-5b4317f6-0398-4688-afa7-8c597e21d86e.png)

> (so I guess it's not the same bug as you fixed, @eenticott-shell)

No it isn't, but I would be happy to take a look at it
